sentence.text: This male newborn was the fifth child to his first cousin Saudi parents who have only one living healthy child because of three neonatal deaths, all reportedly with the same presentation as the index.
Pregnancy was notable for abnormal ultrasounds documenting micromelic fetus.
However, parents decided to carry on with the pregnancy and the patient was born via full term spontaneous vertex delivery.
Apgar scores were 6 and 8 at 1 and 5 min, respectively.
Severe growth retardation was evident, particularly his linear growth (weight 2.1 Kg, length 36.2 cm, OFC 32 cm).
In addition, he was admitted to nursery because of mild respiratory distress that necessitated oxygen supplementation.
His clinical examination revealed abnormally short extremities and clubfeet.
He also had dysmorphic facial features including rounded face, depressed nasal bridge, long philtrum, micrognathia and significant bilateral bluish corneal haziness (Fig. 1).
Additional clinical findings included hypotonia, short neck, small chest, widely spaced nipples, and protuberant abdomen.
There was no cardiac murmur, organomegaly, or genital abnormalities.

Radiographic studies exhibited short tubular bones and typical, albeit severe, Desbuquois hand findings in the form of short metacarpals (especially the first), two extra ossification centers distal to the second and third metacarpals, delta phalanx formation in the first proximal phalanx in addition to several phalangeal dislocations (Fig. 2).
The vertebral bodies showed coronal clefting (Fig. 2).

Similarly characteristic findings were the broad proximal femur with spur-like projection of the lesser trochanters giving some resemblance to “monkey-wrench” or “Swedish key” appearance, in addition to tall ilia and flat acetabular roof.
He had normal hematology indices and renal and liver function tests.
Furthermore, echocardiogram, renal ultrasound and brain CT scan have all shown normal results.
Ophthalmologic evaluation demonstrates bilateral congenital glaucoma.
The patient expired at one month of age from severe respiratory distress.
